bibl.title: Letter from T.H.D. Griffitts to Henry Rose Carter, September 9, 1924

div1.p: Griffitts discusses malaria, mosquitoes and ponds.

div1.head: Letter from T.H.D. Griffitts to Henry Rose Carter, September 9, 1924
div1.opener:
Mal.
Griffitts
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
519 Dexter Avenue,
Montgomery, Ala.,
September 9, 1924.
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
Some time ago I wrote you what, I know, you must
have taken as a rather doleful letter, and I promised
then to write you of business later.

Two ponds I followed as closely last year and this
as could well be done in an unassisted way. The mistake,-
and I am sure you fully recognized it at the time- was in-
not putting Gage with me. I have heard that his last
season's work was of little avail, and Hildebrand tells
me that he is not accomplishing much at Augusta this year.
But that is “water that's over the dam.”

I wrote you last year of the impounded lake of 250 acs
acres near Newton, Houston County (Houston borders on Flor-
ida) on the Little Choctawhatchee River. It was a bad, un-
clean pond made in January 1921. That fall showed a decided
increase in malaria; 1922 much more (history index in 1921,
59% of 168 persons;-1922, 79% of 203 persons). Blood index
(thick) in April, 1923, showed 32.18%. This before flight
of quads. Free “standard treatment” was given under con-
tinuous supervision and very well taken, with still a poi-
positive blood of 26.14 within ten days from and after the last
dose was given. However, 92% of those treated failed to
have any paroxysms after beginning the treatment. I have
written a paper on this work and submitted to Dr. Fricks
some weeks ago. I don't know what he is going to do with
it. I would like for you to read it and criticise it, but
my copy is lent out about the office somewhere just now.

On the pond we cut down production considerably (didn't
have a house check the previous year, so can't say how much)
by the use of Paris green. It wasno't as effective as I ad
hoped for, due largely to the imperfect way it was applied
with $1.25 worth of brain per day. The pond is and was
literally teeming with Gambusia. While the

While the physical condition of the pond was still
very bad at the beginning of the present season--the prev-
alent pine trees shedding much of their bark this year,
I decided it necessary to work out some other and better
method of control. I have succeeded. Am having kerosene
applied under pressure from tanks mounted on Evinrude driven
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
2
or man propelled small boat, as occasion demands. I took
a 40 gal. ordinary hot water tank, provided an air valve
like on an automobile tube. We put 25 gals. of oil in the
tank and give it 120 lbs. pressure. With a rubber hose of
convenient length and a seven foot iron pipe extension,
the man standing in the boat can raise the misty spray
to sufficient height for a fair breeze to carry the oil
for as much as 150 to 200 feet. He raises and lowers test
conditions, or turns on the coarser stream. Lanes are cut
through the brush to permit of weaving in and out. Pro-
duction has been practically nil this season. There is-
no wasteage of oil, its application is not laborious, but
oil, of course, is more expensive than P.g. On this par-
ticular pond we have an electrically driven pump rigged
up with a pressuse tank at the power house, so all there
is to do is to return for a new supply of oils and air
pressure for each 25 gals. It takes 125 gals. each appli-
cation, and through the small hole of the Meyers spray
nozzle, it puts out 1 gal. every 2 1/2 minutes.

As youbprobably know, something had to be done all
of a sudden at Muscle Shoals in July. We started five
boat gangs with the same kind of outfits there, and have
gotten rather good results. I made an inspection of that
filling reservoir the last week in July and it was prodox-
quads. profusely as it filled. For instance, the day be-
fore I was there, there was a rise of six feet, and at pra
tically every selective dip larvae could be dipped. If fb
flotage broke anchorage it soon engaged other nearby ob-
structionn and larvae had little free swimming.

Another thing of practical interest and of money
value in connection with Gambusia development ponds for
new reservoirs. At a great expense the A.P. Co. located 75
Gamb. ponds in the various parts of the basin at Mitchell
Dam. Before the water had reached the maximum level, Gam-
busia had distributed themselves as far as four miles
from the development ponds. In my opinion this is a better
method of distributing them than by scattering their ponds
all about. So, when it came to putting in ponds in the
Cherokee Bluff basin--three times the size of Mitchell-- I
located only 25, and probably cut their expense $10,000.

And speaking of these “hatcheries”. Most of them have
produced Anophelines practically all summer, punctipennis
early, of course. It is naturally punctipennis country;
very limited conditions for quads.-- but note the August
results on the enclosed memo. as to quads. Quads. got in,
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
3
and got in thick and fast. I have seen enough to be con-
vinced that the promiscuous location of even well-stocke-
ponds for minnows may be a serious malaria hazard.

At Muscle Shoals no artificial ponds were located, yet two
or three ponds located near old locks six and seven supplied
the reservoir up to July 25 with enough Gambusia to make
them appear more numerous than in Mitchell reservoir this,
the second, season (It is apparent that they have decidedly
diminished at Mitchell reservoir since last year) the pod
has a good many bass, and the water carries a great deal
of silt for a great deal of the time.

It is getting late and I must go home, but one more
thing on new ponds: In spite of all the preliminary prep-
aration on large ponds, there occurs enough flotage the
first year to call for additional work, minnows or no min-
nows. And the easiest and best method is by pressure tank
oiling!
